ranking.description: This short film 'Rise' from IMDb depicts AI as a dangerous antagonist in a dystopian future, fitting well with the user's request for movies where AI is a killer or antagonist. The source IMDb is credible for movie information.

schema_object.name: Rise
schema_object.description: A dystopian future, where man's attempt to create artificial intelligence has spun wildly out of control, leading to a war between man and machine.

review.name: Great effects and some famous faces, but still just a trailer for an overly familiar sci-fi tale
review.reviewBody:
I've not watched as many shorts as normal of late, but even with a few months off, I probably still saw more 'proof of concept' films than I would have liked. Rise is one of the bigger ones of late, and the hundreds of thousands of views shows that an impressive visual showcase delivered in a tight package will grab those online eyes. Of course proof of concept is not the same as proving you can make a good short film – but then, this is not really the goal here. There is a certain amount of universe creation, and a scenario is played out, however it never doesn't feel like a trailer which runs long.

Visually there is a lot of very impressive work here. The tight editing makes the most of the dramatic scenes and footage, while the effects are very well done. The merging of humans and robots is particularly convincing in how it looks and moves. The money spent on this is certainly right there to be seen. As a story though, it all feels so very familiar that it didn't really excite me to get into it more. The familiar faces (Sewell, Yelchin, Kang) add to this feeling of it having quality, but like the effects, it only works on the level as a trailer.

Hard to complain, because it delivers what it set out to do, and it certainly got the views it wanted, however if you are looking for anything more than a professionally produced trailer then Rise will not do much for you.

review.name: God of the str8 to videos!!!
review.reviewBody: Everyone is trying to say this is suppose to be a comedy. I have a collection of around 300 movies and alot of them are funny as hell but not classified as comedy. Lethal Weapon 4 for example had more humor in it than Death Machine. This is a great movie with a strong resemblance to Aliens, not Alien despite public opinion. The costume design on the Hardman suit was very good for a low budget film. The camera work was really good especially in certain scenes where several emotions are caught in them. The movie features a good plot and believable tech for the year it takes place in. It does feature some cheesy lines in a couple of parts but other than that its dialogue is strong. Our tree hugging heros are very likable too. In my own humble opinion which of course is the only one that matters, if this were re-released as a theatrical motion picture, it'd be the action flick of the summer next year! This one gets a 9!

ranking.description: Highly relevant movie from a credible source (IMDb) depicting AI as a central antagonist through an experimental computer chip implant used for revenge, fitting the user's request for films where AI acts as a killer or antagonist.

schema_object.name: Upgrade
schema_object.description: Set in the near-future, technology controls nearly all aspects of life. But when the world of Grey, a self-labeled technophobe, is turned upside down, his only hope for revenge is an experimental computer chip implant.

review.name: Well worth the price of a ticket
review.reviewBody:
I went into this with fairly low expectations. The trailer looked good, and the cinematography looked exciting. But the premise seemed tired and worn.

*in a deep, movie-voice over voice* some guys kill his wife, and now he's seeking revenge". 

But this film surpassed my expectations, and was a well-worth experience. Not only was I correct about the cinematography being exciting and engaging, but the plot actually strung together compelling way. This film came out of nowhere for me, and now, it's a memorable film that accomplishes the most important goal of any great film: gets the audience to keep wondering about it.

Since I don't want to go into spoilers, I'll say one last thing: pay attention to the Foley artist's work. The sound design is poignant and additive to the experience. It reminds me of the clever usage of music from Baby Driver. Nothing is wasted and is always enriching of the world building. With Baby Driver, the music was giving us Baby's personal experience. Here, the sound effects give us Grey's point of view. Didn't experiences, but both are elevated through sound, masterfully.

I genuinely want to see it again. If the trailer interested you at all, go see it. It's worth your while.

name: Minority Report

ranking.description: The movie 'Minority Report' involves futuristic crime prevention with precognitive technology but does not depict AI as a killer or antagonist, making it only marginally relevant to the user's request for movies featuring AI as antagonists.

schema_object.name: Minority Report
schema_object.description: John works with the PreCrime police which stop crimes before they take place, with the help of three 'PreCogs' who can foresee crimes. Events ensue when John finds himself framed for a future murder.

review.name: One of the best/most complex science fiction films
review.reviewBody:
Steven Spielberg sets Minority Report in the near future of 2054, in which the technology is advanced, but not far-fetched. Cars can drive themselves and ride up elevators, computers come with holograms as a user interface, and stores recognize you from your eyeball scan. As all science fiction fans know, however, the genre is not about technology but about ideas. The big idea for Minority Report is based on a short story by the venerable Philip K. Dick. In this future, there is a "pre-crime" unit in the police force, which revolves around three psychics who are able to see violent crimes before they occur. These visions are projected in a flat screen panel and manipulated by detectives with the grace of a symphony conductor. Equipped with futuristic stun guns, jet packs, and search robots, these cops then arrest and intern the criminals before the crimes are committed.

We learn all this in the first ten minutes of the movie. After this introduction, the plot really starts when Detective John Anderton (Tom Cruise) finds out that the precogs saw him kill someone, someone that he has never met. He finds himself in a race. With the forced recruitment of a precog, Agatha (Samantha Morton), he must clear his name before the predetermined murder. All the while, his old buddies, now helped with a special agent from the FBI (Colin Farrell), are trying to track him down.

Spielberg, with Janusz Kaminski, his cinematographer for many films, have crafted a visually stunning movie. The special effects are seamlessly incorporated of the world they created. The muted blues echo the style of black & white film noirs. John Anderton is similar to noir's morally ambiguous characters--a good cop with an illegal habit that is forced (by circumstances and desire) to betray the very things he loves.

But this is not just a special effects or mystery movie. The characters, all well drawn, are supremely acted by the cast. Tom Cruise is a good physical actor and he shows it here. By the way he sits or walks, we can intuit the grief and confusion that's going through him. Samantha Morton does a good job of portraying a haunted young lady who has seen too much. Colin Farrell skillfully balances the ambitious and professional sides of his character. As always, Max von Sydow authoritatively plays the respected father figure.

This is one of my favorite Science Fiction films. I would also recommend the following films. These (I think) influenced Minority Report.

"The Maltese Falcon" ~ film noir "A Clockwork Orange" ~ science fiction "Blade Runner" ~ science fiction (also based on a Dick story)

***** out of *****

name: The Drake-Kendrick Lamar Beef

schema_object.name: The Drake-Kendrick Lamar Beef
schema_object.description:
2024 seems destined to go down as the Year of Pop Culture Grievances. Megan vs. Nicki. Beyoncé vs. Nashville. But above all: Kendrick Lamar vs. Drake, who are currently engaged in the nastiest lyrical warfare rap fans have seen in a minute. Today, we're talking about all the pettiness: Why so much beef, and what makes a good battle? And is there ever a clear "winner" in these battles?

Learn more about sponsor message choices: podcastchoices.com/adchoices

NPR Privacy Policy

partOfSeries.name: Pop Culture Happy Hour
partOfSeries.description:
Get obsessed with us. Five days a week, Pop Culture Happy Hour serves you recommendations and commentary on the buzziest movies, TV, music, books, videogames and more. Join arts journalists Linda Holmes, Glen Weldon, Stephen Thompson, and Aisha Harris - plus a rotating cast of guest pop culture aficionados. The Happy Hour team leaves room at the table for exploring a range of reactions and opinions on every bit of the pop universe. From lowbrow to highbrow to the stuff in between, they take it all with a shot of cheer.

Make your happy hour even happier with Pop Culture Happy Hour Plus! Your subscription supports the podcast and unlocks a sponsor-free feed. Learn more at plus.npr.org/happyhour

name: The Day The Mixtape Died: DJ Drama

ranking.description: This NPR podcast episode from the series 'Louder Than A Riot' explores the cultural and legal tensions surrounding mixtapes in hip-hop, highlighting the conflict between artistic innovation and commercial/legal pressures, making it highly relevant to discussions on art versus commercial interests in the hip-hop industry.

schema_object.name: The Day The Mixtape Died: DJ Drama
schema_object.description:
In the early 2000s, mixtapes transformed Tyree Simmons into DJ Drama and molded T.I., Lil Wayne and Jeezy into rap superstars. But in 2007, those same mixtapes landed Drama in jail with a bank account balance of $0.00. In this episode, we break down the raid that turned the mixtape from cultural innovation into criminal conspiracy, from the perspective of the man who took the fall when the cops came knocking. "If they can lock up Drama, nobody's safe. It's over."

Learn more about sponsor message choices: podcastchoices.com/adchoices

NPR Privacy Policy

partOfSeries.name: Louder Than A Riot
partOfSeries.description:
Hip-hop emerged from the voices of the unheard. But freedom doesn't ring the same for everyone. Inside all corners of the culture, Black women and queer folk have dealt with the same oppression the music was built to escape. Season 2 of Louder Than A Riot examines who hip-hop marginalizes, and how misogynoir — the specific racist misogyny against Black women — is embedded into the fabric of the culture that we love.

From Rico Nasty facing harassment from toxic fans, to Saucy Santana's unapologetically femme aesthetics in a queerphobic industry, to the assault case that put Megan Thee Stallion's image on trial, each episode of Louder Than A Riot unpacks the unspoken rules of rap that discriminate against a select few and have held the entire culture back.

Hosted by NPR Music's Sidney Madden and Rodney Carmichael, Louder Than A Riot confronts power from every angle – from the power the genre wields over its artists, to the power plays that its rulebreakers take in order to get heard. In the midst of a so-called Renaissance for women in rap, these stories reveal a rot at the core of the culture that reflects how voices, bodies, and rights are still policed in America.

partOfSeries.name: The Cobain 50
partOfSeries.description: Kurt Cobain’s influence went beyond just the music he created with Nirvana. He also put the masses on to some of his own favorite artists. One particular document from his journals has been instructive to many fans – his top 50 albums. Each week, The Cobain 50 podcast digs into albums from this famous list and how they may have influenced Cobain and Nirvana. While learning the individual histories of the different albums on the list, we gain new insights into artists on the fringes as well as some of the biggest groups of all time. The podcast takes us through the legacies of acts like Sonic Youth, Pixies, The Breeders, Public Enemy, PJ Harvey, Black Flag, Mazzy Star, The Shaggs, Shonen Knife, and more. Episodes drop weekly starting January 10, 2024.

name: Peacemaking in Hip Hop Music

ranking.description: This podcast episode from Peace Talks Radio discusses hip hop culture with a focus on peacemaking and spirituality, touching on critiques of the genre. While it does not explicitly focus on the tension between art and commercial interests, it provides relevant cultural context and credible perspectives from artists and activists, making it moderately relevant to the user's question.

schema_object.name: Peacemaking in Hip Hop Music
schema_object.description:
When some talk about music that promotes peacemaking, hip hop and rap
often get left out of the conversation. Some critics speculate about that
genre’s negative influence - from hypersexual music videos to glamorizing
guns and drugs. A recent Washington Post headline quotes jazz musician
Wynton Marsalis calling popular hip hop “more damaging than a statue of
Robert E. Lee.”

In this episode of Peace Talks Radio, Hannah Colton explores peacemaking
in hip hop culture and history with one documentarian and one artist.
First, Hannah speaks with Brother Ali, a Minneapolis-based rapper,
community organizer and spiritual teacher. Ali, who is white, was born
albino and partially blind, and says as a kid he found belonging in the
black community and hip hop culture. As a young man he converted to Islam,
and he speaks to ideas of spirituality in his 2017 album “All The Beauty
In This Whole Life.”

Then Hannah speaks with Harry Allen, a hip hop activist who has written
for many publications including the Village Voice, The Source, Essence and
Wired magazines.

partOfSeries.name: Peace Talks Radio
partOfSeries.description: A monthly series on peacemaking and nonviolent conflict resolution. Stories that inform, inspire and improve the human condition.

name: How the 90s Changed Hip Hop

ranking.description: This podcast episode from KEXP's 'A Deeper Listen' series critically examines the impact of industry consolidation on hip hop, highlighting the tension between commercial interests and authentic artistic expression, making it highly relevant to discussions on art versus commerce in hip hop.

schema_object.name: How the 90s Changed Hip Hop
schema_object.description:
DJ and professor Davey D along with KEXP’s Gabriel Teodros discuss how consolidation and the Telecommunications Act of 1996 drove out small, independent and Black-owned radio stations. The resulting centralized playlists hid more independent and socially conscious hip hop artists from the mainstream eye.

“It’s the same five artists over and over again. What do they talk about? They talk about money, sex and things that are dehumanizing. What does that mean when white America is learning about Black humanity through this very narrow lens that only a few executives that are not from the culture are painting? It becomes an attack,” Teodros says.

Support the show: https://www.kexp.org/sound/

See omnystudio.com/listener for privacy information.

partOfSeries.name: A Deeper Listen
partOfSeries.description: On A Deeper Listen, host Emily Fox and other storytellers from KEXP talk with artists about the stories behind their songs and the experiences that inform their work. Through each conversation, we uncover the humanity behind the music, allowing us to hear it in a whole new way.

schema_object.name: Shea Serrano answers existential questions about rap in 'Hip Hop (And Other Things)'
schema_object.description:
Author and host of the No Skips podcast Shea Serrano gets obsessive about things — movies, basketball, and now, rap. You can follow us on Twitter at @NPRItsBeenAMin and email us at samsanders@npr.org.

partOfSeries.name: It's Been a Minute
partOfSeries.description:
Has it been a minute since you heard a thought-provoking conversation about culture? Brittany Luse wants to help. Each week, she takes the things everyone's talking about and, in conversation with her favorite creators, tastemakers, and experts, gives you new ways to think about them. Beyond the obvious takes. Because culture doesn't happen by accident.

If you can't get enough, try It's Been a Minute Plus. Your subscription supports the show and unlocks a sponsor-free feed. Learn more at plus.npr.org/itsbeenaminute

partOfSeries.name: The Cobain 50
partOfSeries.description: Kurt Cobain’s influence went beyond just the music he created with Nirvana. He also put the masses on to some of his own favorite artists. One particular document from his journals has been instructive to many fans – his top 50 albums. Each week, The Cobain 50 podcast digs into albums from this famous list and how they may have influenced Cobain and Nirvana. While learning the individual histories of the different albums on the list, we gain new insights into artists on the fringes as well as some of the biggest groups of all time. The podcast takes us through the legacies of acts like Sonic Youth, Pixies, The Breeders, Public Enemy, PJ Harvey, Black Flag, Mazzy Star, The Shaggs, Shonen Knife, and more. Episodes drop weekly starting January 10, 2024.

name: The Conspiracy Against Hip-Hop

ranking.description: This NPR podcast episode from the series 'Louder Than A Riot' explores systemic issues within hip-hop culture, including power dynamics and marginalization, which closely relates to the tension between artistic expression and commercial or societal pressures in the hip-hop industry. NPR's credibility and the episode's focus on cultural and industry power struggles make it highly relevant to the user's question.

schema_object.name: The Conspiracy Against Hip-Hop
schema_object.description:
In this first episode, a mysterious conspiracy letter sends us on a journey to find out just how entangled hip-hop and mass incarceration have become over the last 40 years. We travel back in time to 1980s Atlanta with Killer Mike, 1990s Oakland with Too Short and beyond. From Reagan's war on drugs to a secret NYPD dossier of the world's biggest rappers, it's all connected — and, as Killer Mike says, "The proof's in the pudding."

Learn more about sponsor message choices: podcastchoices.com/adchoices

NPR Privacy Policy

partOfSeries.name: Louder Than A Riot
partOfSeries.description:
Hip-hop emerged from the voices of the unheard. But freedom doesn't ring the same for everyone. Inside all corners of the culture, Black women and queer folk have dealt with the same oppression the music was built to escape. Season 2 of Louder Than A Riot examines who hip-hop marginalizes, and how misogynoir — the specific racist misogyny against Black women — is embedded into the fabric of the culture that we love.

From Rico Nasty facing harassment from toxic fans, to Saucy Santana's unapologetically femme aesthetics in a queerphobic industry, to the assault case that put Megan Thee Stallion's image on trial, each episode of Louder Than A Riot unpacks the unspoken rules of rap that discriminate against a select few and have held the entire culture back.

Hosted by NPR Music's Sidney Madden and Rodney Carmichael, Louder Than A Riot confronts power from every angle – from the power the genre wields over its artists, to the power plays that its rulebreakers take in order to get heard. In the midst of a so-called Renaissance for women in rap, these stories reveal a rot at the core of the culture that reflects how voices, bodies, and rights are still policed in America.

itemReviewed.name: Berryessa Peak Trail

schema_object.reviewBody: This hike will test your physical abilities and even your mental resolve. I'm used to difficult hikes, so this one for me, was a moderate challenge. This hike is not for people who are out of shape, who have bad balance, a fear of heights, or people with no patience. As others have said, bring plenty of water. It was cold and mostly cloudy on my hike, so I only drank about 1 liter of water, but I brought 2 liters. Others have recommended bringing at least 2 liters for cool days and at least 3 liters or more on warmer days. The first 1.5 miles is easy, with a slight incline through the oak studded rolling hills. There are at least 10 creek crossings though, in that stretch. My boots did get a bit wet despite walking on the rocks or hopping to get across. BTW, trekking poles were pretty much a must on this hike. Then after all the creek crossings, the trail starts a more substantial climb, but nothing tricky yet. But then the trail narrows to a boot wide and more or less follows the contour of an extremely steep hillside. This goes on for a long while. You do NOT want to slip or lose your balance on this! You WILL fall down a 60 degree decline a long ways if you fall. I used the trekking poles on this risky stretch for extra balance and support, just in case. There is a small washout in the trail that's too dangerous to cross because the mountainside is so incredibly steep, so go up and around it, which wasn't hard for me to do. The mountainside eventually gets less steep, but the narrow trail now goes through chaparral brush, so keep a close eye on where the trail goes. At one point you'll cross a landslide of boulders, so watch your footing. As it continues through the sagebrush, it drops down in elevation a ways until you cross a creek. Before the creek I think, at about 4.8 miles, there is a piece of bent rebar sticking out of the trail in a horrible spot. I'm so glad I saw it in time. It is a bad tripping hazard. You'll fall facefirst into the scratchy bushes if you trip on it. So watch carefully for it! If it's rained recently, it's steep, muddy and slippery as the trail descends to the creek. My trekking poles made things so much easier here. After crossing the creek, pay attention to where the trail goes. Your GPS will be your friend from here. Previously, the trail was very easy to follow, but it requires a lot of focus to keep track of the trail as it climbs up the other side through more chaparral brush. I think you'll cross a 2nd creek before climbing back up. As you're climbing up the other side, the bushes get taller and very scratchy. Wear long pants and a long sleeve shirt or else you'll get seriously scratched up. You're going to be fighting a seemingly endless amount of overgrown brush, that will be pulling your hair, snagging on anything on your backpack, scratching up against your arms and even neck at times. As you reach the rocky ridge, the bushes thin out somewhat for some amazing views, but it gets muddy and slippery again at times. Eventually, you'll be nearing a dirt access road, but before you get there, you'll be descending into seriously thick and tall brush that's denser than ever and it really becomes hard to see where the trail goes. Once again, you'll be getting all scratched up if you aren't covering your arms and legs. Fortunately, this is short lived and you'll come to the access road. Make a mental note of where the trail meets the road or use your GPS to find it on the way back. The dirt road is a huge relief and break from all that bushwhacking. It climbs gently for that last mile or so to the summit. The summit is by the radio towers. The views are incredible! You can see Mt Tam, Diablo, the Sierras and I could even see Mount Shasta. Lake Berryessa sits in all its glory below. Heading back was about the same adventure as going up. However, I slipped a bunch of times on the way back but never fell. I also kept tripping on those stubs that were once bushes. But still never fell. When I was about 2 miles from the car I saw a huge bobcat on the hiking trail. I mean, a really big boy! When he saw me, he lowered his body like a housecat does before charging and pouncing. So I climbed a hill to flank him in order to avoid him, and he suddenly darted away. I never saw him again. Anyway, this hike is an excellent workout and a good challenge, but definitely not for the faint of heart.
schema_object.author: Seth H

itemReviewed.name: Poison Oak Valley to Saddle Trail

schema_object.reviewBody: The directions link for this trail took us to a side street which was about .4 miles from the actual trail head.  When you get to the beginning of the trail, there are restrooms. There is no charge for access or parking.  The trail was done CCW which will take you up some gradual hills and down some steep ones. The trails are dirt or clay  with rocks.  They are deeply rutted and very steep in places.  Would advice avoiding if it has been raining recently.  Some of the trails are very narrow.  A small section of the loop is on the street.     There were dog walkers sharing the trail and a rare biker.  Hiking boots and poles are very useful.  The trails are not marked well.  There are few signs.  I had to frequently check AllTrails to be sure I was on the right track and still made some wrong turns.  The loop is about 50% shaded.  There are some nice valley and neighborhood  views and from the top of sugarloaf there are expansive views of the bay.  The trees along the loop are mostly oaks which are nicely spaced so you can see the terrain.  There were alot of interesting mushrooms/fungi along the trail.  My mileage was 3.9 with 660 elevation gain (my AllTrails map mistakenly paused after 2.7 miles).  I would give this 3 stars   for the views and rate this is moderate difficulty due to the steep and rutted sections.
schema_object.author: Alan Schwartz

itemReviewed.name: Stevens Creek Nature Trail Loop

schema_object.reviewBody: This loop trail gives a great view of the Stevens Creek Canyon, and how steep and rugged the Santa Cruz mountains really are. The top part of the trail skirts an abandoned walnut orchard and an abandoned stock watering pond, part of Governor Sunny Jim Rolph’s vast Alpine Ranch (as is the Los Trancos Open Space Preserve). The east side of the loop is I think, an old ranch road. It was 82 degrees when I set out, and the parts of the trail in open grassland were pretty warm, but most of the trail is shaded by mixed forest: Douglas fir, bay trees, and the like.
schema_object.author: Liz Ditz

itemReviewed.name: Blackstone, Queenstone, and Valleystone

schema_object.reviewBody:
I can’t think of many places where you can see Tam, Diablo, Helena, Sonoma Mtns, and Olompali from one spot. The section of footpath that’s parallel and upslope from Chicken Shack FR has such a spot. 
The section of trail between the creek crossing and Ponti Ridge Trail sucks and requires a lot of patience—very steep. I wouldn’t want to do it without poles., That creek crossing was a bit of a challenge today (Saturday) after heavy rains on Mon-Tue and Thurs this week. 
 However, the patient, intrepid, and fit hiker is well rewarded with waterfalls and great views. I’d do it again.
schema_object.author: Dana Coe

schema_object.reviewBody: In the Summer the open ridge can get hot.  The shaded areas are about 10 degrees cooler than the sunny areas.  The first part of the hike has a climb, but after the first 3/4 miles there is shade and the trail goes down to Alpine Lake.  If you haven't been to the Butano View, I would take the 0.2 mile detour near the tops of the trail.  The trail is not spectacular, but when you add Alpine Lake and views of the Redwood Forests to the west it is worth the hike.  Alpine Lake is a nice place to take a little break or have lunch.  There is shade, picnic tables, and wildlife (rabbits, turtles, quail).  The Visitor Center is open Saturday & Sunday 12 noon - 5:00pm in the Spring & Summer, 11:00 am - 4:00 pm in the Fall and Winter.  Check the Daniel C Daniels Nature Center website for updated hours.
schema_object.author: Hamby Aochi

itemReviewed.name: Ridge Trail, Peters Creek, and Canyon Trail Loop

schema_object.reviewBody:
Started from Monte Bello Open Space Preserve, reached Turtle Rock (awesome view), descended Table Mountain Trail (steep), crossed the creek (barely any water as of 8/25/24, can be crossed easily), back up the Canyon Trail (fire road). Logged 22.5k on my AW. 

Positives: lots of shaded area through the woods and single tracks. The view from Turtle Rock was awesome. Creek crossing was  nice addition. Trail in a good condition. 

Negatives: quite many mt bikers, met 10+ on Sunday in a span of 2.5hrs of my run. Poison oaks on the side, but wasn’t an issue, just stay on the trail. It can get hot when exposed, this time of the year
schema_object.author: Jo Schlemper

name: Women's High Tops FAQ

ranking.description: This FAQ from a reputable shoe brand provides detailed information on Allbirds shoes, highlighting their comfort, versatility, and suitability for all-day wear, which aligns well with the user's interest in shoes that are comfortable for both parties and office settings.

mainEntity.name: What's the difference between mid-tops and high-tops?

acceptedAnswer.text: The main distinction between mid-tops and high-tops is the amount of ankle coverage. Mid-top shoes typically go up to the ankle, while high-top shoes fully cover the ankle, providing a slight increase in stability and support.

mainEntity.name: How long does it take to break in Allbirds?

acceptedAnswer.text: If your Allbirds wool-based shoes fit tightly at first, don’t fret — they are likely to stretch about a quarter of an inch after the first few weeks of wearing them. (However, our Tree-based shoes will maintain their initial shape.) Regardless of the type of shoe, we suggest wearing your Allbirds for 1-2 weeks to break them in properly.

mainEntity.name: Are Allbirds comfortable to wear all day?

acceptedAnswer.text:
Absolutely! Every Allbirds shoe is designed with all-day comfort in mind. Our everyday shoes, such as the Wool Mizzles, Tree Dashers, and Wool Pipers are made with sustainable, ethically-sourced materials like cozy ZQ Merino wool, bouncy SweetFoam® sugarcane midsoles, and cushiony, odor-reducing castor bean oil insoles—all of which combine to create a light, breathable, flexible, and ultra-comfortable shoe. Show off your Allbirds and feel great doing it—from working to running errands, and everything in between.

Learn more about our materials.

schema_object.name: Women's High Tops FAQ

name: The Cold Weather Shop FAQ

ranking.description: This FAQ from a reputable footwear brand provides detailed information on versatile wool shoes that are comfortable and stylish, suitable for casual and office settings, making it fairly relevant to finding nice shoes for relaxing, parties, and office wear.

mainEntity.name: What are the best cold weather shoes?

acceptedAnswer.text: Frozen feet are the worst. Cozy up in ZQ merino wool uppers with our ever-popular Wool Runners—they’re simple, cool, and versatile enough to take you from shopping to walking the dog, no matter the weather. Or, try a slip-on and get going even faster. The men’s Wool Loungers are a cold-weather essential. No more icy breezes while you’re on your daily walks!

mainEntity.name: Why is wool used in cold weather shoes?

acceptedAnswer.text:
Using wool to create clothing and textiles for chilly weather is certainly not a new idea—humankind has relied on this thoughtful gift from herds of fluffy, highly generous sheep for centuries. And for good reason: wool is quite warm! So, it was a natural choice (literally) for our, shall we say, warmer versions of our shoes. 

But we don’t just use any wool—Allbirds specifically uses ZQ Merino wool for our products. Not only is it superfine, ultra-soft, temperature-regulating, moisture-wicking, and completely itch-free, it’s also a renewable material sourced from happy, healthy merino sheep in New Zealand. (Learn more about our ZQ Merino wool and other sustainable materials.)

You can find ZQ Merino wool on many of our best-selling shoes, like the Wool Runners and Wool Pipers. Need a comfy pair of slip-on shoes for cold weather that keep your feet warm yet breathable? Take a look at the Wool Loungers.

mainEntity.name: Does Allbirds have winter shoes for running?

acceptedAnswer.text: Don’t let cold temps keep you inside. Many fans enjoy a run in our Wool Runners, but we also invite you to take a good, long look at our Wool Dasher Mizzles. Think of them as a more souped-up version of the Tree Dasher 2: They offer the same comfort and warmth along with some strategic features like a flared outsole for better stability, a tread design that can handle wet and slippery surfaces, and water-repellent Puddle Guard® technology to keep your feet dry, whether walking or running (or jogging, or briskly walking).

mainEntity.name: What are the Ideal Men’s Winter Sneakers?

acceptedAnswer.text:
Finding a pair of sneakers to rely on through the winter months can be a bit difficult—especially if you’re looking for a versatile shoe that can be worn for everything from running errands to workdays at the office. It’s time to get acquainted with our Wool Runners, with minimalist styling and cozy interior. 

With super soft ZQ Merino wool on the outside, your feet will remain warm and comfy throughout the day, even when the wind chill refuses to chill. But don’t worry—they still offer ample breathability, so things don’t get too stuffy as the minutes add up. You’ll find that same soft, itch-free, moisture-wicking ZQ Merino wool on the inside as well, along with a bouncy midsole made from Brazilian sugarcane. Soft, stable, warm, and effortlessly stylish, Wool Runners are the perfect winter sneaker. Tread accordingly.

schema_object.name: The Cold Weather Shop FAQ

name: Women's Travel Essentials FAQ

ranking.description: This FAQ from a women's travel essentials site offers detailed recommendations for comfortable, stylish shoes suitable for travel, meetings, and casual outings, making it fairly relevant for someone seeking versatile shoes to relax in and wear to parties or the office.

mainEntity.name: What are the best travel shoes for women?

acceptedAnswer.text:
Whether you’re driving across the country or hopping flights, choosing shoes with exceptional comfort and breathable materials will help you focus on your connection and not your feet.

We especially like slip-on shoes for traveling. Check out our Tree Loungers or Tree Dasher Relays for easy sneaks to get you from point A to point B. If you’re a fan of flats, try our Tree Breezers. Not only are these light and airy, you’ll look stylish and ready to head straight to your meeting or restaurant reservations.

For a lighter-than-air option, take a look at the SuperLight collection, our everyday sneakers that are ultralight with super low carbon footprints. 

If you’re traveling to a rainy or snowy destination but have zero intention of wearing boots, we’ve got you covered. Try the Wool Runners—they’re water resistant and made with soft merino wool uppers. You can exit the plane and splash on over to your driver or your subway stop without losing on warmth or comfort.

Read much more on Choosing the Right Travel Shoes for you.

name: Men's Everyday Sneakers FAQ

ranking.description: This FAQ from a shoe brand provides useful general advice on shoe longevity, sizing, and care, which is somewhat relevant to choosing comfortable everyday shoes. However, it lacks specific recommendations for shoes suitable for both parties and office settings, limiting its direct applicability to the user's question about versatile, stylish, and relaxing footwear.

mainEntity.name: How long should everyday shoes last?

acceptedAnswer.text:
As a general rule of thumb, everyday shoes should be replaced every 9-12 months or when they start showing signs of wear and tear.

Because we want you to wear your Allbirds for a long time and reduce the waste that comes with replacing shoes needlessly, replacing the insoles can extend the life of the shoe and keep them feeling cushy and comfortable. Try Allbirds’ premium, high-cushion insoles, lined with our Merino wool. If your laces are giving out on you, you can also pick up new replacement laces, which are made with post-consumer plastic bottles. (One pair of shoelaces equals 1 recycled water bottle!) Learn more about proper care for your Allbirds shoes here.

mainEntity.name: How often should you buy new walking shoes?

acceptedAnswer.text: If you spend 30 minutes a day walking — which averages to around 3-4 hours weekly — it's advisable to replace your shoes every 9-12 months. On the other hand, if you walk for 60 minutes daily or roughly 7 hours per week, it's recommended to change your shoes more often.

mainEntity.name: Is it better to buy shoes bigger or smaller?

acceptedAnswer.text:
There should be roughly half an inch of space between your longest toe and the shoe's front. Going for a shoe that is slightly bigger than your foot allows for improved circulation and reduces swelling. Plus, no one wants that pinched feeling on their toes!

If one foot is somewhat larger than the other, go with the larger size, and always take into account the type of socks you intend to wear with your shoes. See Size Chart

schema_object.name: Men's Everyday Sneakers FAQ

name: Women's Flats FAQ

ranking.description: This FAQ from a reputable footwear brand provides detailed information on women's flats, emphasizing comfort, versatility, and suitability for various occasions including walking and standing all day. It aligns well with the user's query about nice shoes for relaxing, parties, and office wear, highlighting breathable materials and stylish options, though it focuses specifically on flats rather than a broader range of shoe types.

mainEntity.name: Are the flats comfortable?

acceptedAnswer.text: We may be biased here, but there’s a reason the Tree Breezer flats get stellar reviews. Made with our responsibly sourced eucalyptus tree fiber knit, these flats feel cool, breathable, and silky smooth on your feet. The springy outsoles are made from sugarcane in a material we call SweetFoam®, made with the world’s first carbon negative green EVA. With a bit of ribbing to keep them snug on your foot plus a dash of color if you choose, these flats are extremely comfortable and versatile.

mainEntity.name: Should flats be tight or loose?

acceptedAnswer.text:
Is it ok if we say they should fit ‘just right’? Flats that fit too tightly will cause blisters and pain, especially on your heel and toes. But flats that are too loose will slip around, which can also cause blisters from that friction. And what’s just as bothersome—they won’t stay on your feet.

Like other shoes, flats should be snug enough to not slip when you walk, but not so tight that they hurt. A rule of thumb: there should be a very slight gap between your heel and the shoe.

mainEntity.name: Are flats good for walking?

acceptedAnswer.text:
Go for it! Flats are refreshingly versatile—and that includes being able to wear them walking, shopping, doing errands, and whatever else your day brings. So yes, flats are good for walking.

If you’re looking for a comfortable shoe to wear while standing all day or working on your feet, flats can be a great option instead of heels. Your toes won’t feel as much pressure—and your legs will probably thank you, too. If you’re planning on a long, athletic walk, try the Tree Dasher.

mainEntity.name: Do you wear flats with or without socks?

acceptedAnswer.text:
Most people wear flats without socks. Allbirds flats are made with renewable, silky-smooth eucalyptus tree fiber—a breathable thermo-regulating material that keeps your feet airy and comfy. And if you ever want to wash your Allbirds, you can do so, no sweat. Just take out the insoles and either hand wash or machine wash on gentle/cold. Air dry, and off you go!

Of course, if you want to wear flats with socks, we won’t stop you. You do you.

schema_object.name: Women's Flats FAQ

name: Men's Active Shoes FAQ

ranking.description: This FAQ from a reputable shoe brand provides detailed information on comfortable, versatile shoes suitable for walking, running, and casual wear, highlighting models that offer cushioning and style potentially fitting for both office and party settings. However, it focuses more on active and running shoes rather than explicitly addressing shoes ideal for relaxing or formal occasions.

mainEntity.name: Is it OK to walk long distances with running shoes?

acceptedAnswer.text:
Absolutely! Running shoes are made for heel-to-toe motion and offer loads of cushioning and support, so go ahead and walk in your running shoes. With lightweight uppers and midsoles that keep you springy and steady, you can use that energy return on your walk just as well as on your runs. 

Although engineered for running, the Tree Flyers and Tree Dashers are ideal walking shoes. Lightweight, durable, and exceptionally comfortable, these shoes offer a cushioned SwiftFoam midsole that enhances energy return, making extended walks easier on your body. A breathable eucalyptus tree fiber upper guarantees comfort across all distances, while a geometric midsole ensure effortless stability for miles.

Looking to tackle off-road terrain? The Trail Runners SWT are water-resistant hiking shoes with rugged, all-condition traction and stabilizing midsole support. Tough on trails and easy on the planet!

mainEntity.name: Which Allbirds shoes are best for running?

acceptedAnswer.text:
We recommend the Tree Dasher 2 for most everyday runs. It hits the sweet spot of both performance and minimal environmental impact. The Tree Dasher has a breathable, flexible eucalyptus tree fiber upper, a responsive SweetFoam midsole derived from sugarcane, and a natural rubber outsole for grip.

For extended runs, lace up the Tree Flyers. This shoe is lightweight, highly resilient, and ultra-comfortable for distance running. The cushioned SwiftFoam midsole is optimized for energy return—making long runs gentler on your body—and it features a breathable eucalyptus tree fiber upper for comfort over any distance.

For off-road and trail running, go with the Trail Runners SWT. These shoes come with a lugged outsole for improved grip and traction on various off-road surfaces, a toe bumper for added protection in rough terrain, and a reinforced heel counter with a supportive midsole to enhance stability and support on uneven ground.

mainEntity.name: Are Allbirds shoes good for running?

acceptedAnswer.text:
You better believe it! Try any of the athletic shoes on this page for comfortable running shoes made with renewable materials. 

Looking for a recommendation? The Tree Flyers are so comfy your runs may go faster and longer. Remarkably lightweight, impressively bouncy, and incredibly cozy, this distance running shoe makes every mile feel a little easier. An advanced, high-performance SwiftFoam midsole offers ample cushioning and energy return to ensure long runs are gentler on your body.

mainEntity.name: Is it better to have 2 pairs of running shoes?

acceptedAnswer.text: It depends on how often you run. If you run four or more times a week, you should have at least two pairs of shoes. Keeping two different pairs of running shoes on hand allows your shoes to decompress from day to day. Plus, you can dedicate certain shoes to certain running conditions or scenarios. For instance, the Tree Flyer is made for longer-distance runs while the Mizzles are water-resistant so they’re great for splashy outings. Trail Runners SWT are great for trail running or hiking.

mainEntity.name: Can I wear jogging shoes all day?

acceptedAnswer.text: Absolutely! Allbirds jogging shoes are made for all-day comfortable wear, no matter what activity is in store. Plus, Allbirds are versatile enough that you can wear them to a restaurant or to a gym and not look out of place.

schema_object.name: Men's Active Shoes FAQ

name: Men's Slip-Ons FAQ

ranking.description: This FAQ from Allbirds provides detailed information on men's slip-on shoes known for comfort and versatility, making them relevant for users seeking shoes suitable for relaxing, parties, and office wear. The brand's credibility and focus on comfort enhance its cross-site relevance, though it primarily targets travel and casual use rather than formal office settings explicitly.

mainEntity.name: What are the best slip-on shoes for the airport and travel?

acceptedAnswer.text:
Allbirds offers two shoes that are ideal for going from plane to pavement. Whether you’re headed straight to the hotel or checking out the sites and sounds of the city, slip-ons are a great solution for on-the-go travelers. 

Our Tree Loungers are easy breezy and lightweight. Slip them on and off going through airport security, and enjoy their breathable comfort and versatility every other moment of your trip. (If your travels are taking you to colder climates, we recommend going with the Wool Loungers for added warmth.) 

The Tree Dasher Relay offers the look and feel of a running shoe, but has a seamless one-piece upper. The lightly padded heel collar keeps your shoes in place during those long walks through the terminal and wherever else your steps take you.

mainEntity.name: Should you wear socks with slip-on shoes?

acceptedAnswer.text:
The choice is entirely up to you! Some Allbirds wearers are perfectly fine going sockless in their slip-on shoes, but like any shoe, going without socks for an extended period of time may result in chaffing and blisters on your bare feet, especially if you are logging a high amount of steps on a regular basis. 

That said, if you want that sleek, no-sock look with your slip-ons, we recommend our Trino™ Anytime No Show Sock.

mainEntity.name: Are Allbirds shoes itchy?

acceptedAnswer.text:
Nope! Allbirds shoes are designed with comfort at the forefront and feature our signature ZQ-Certified merino wool, which is softer and less irritating than regular wool. With fibers that are 20% the diameter of human hair, our superfine merino wool is breathable and moisture-wicking, plus it’s a renewable resource, thanks to our free-spirited Allbirds sheep. 

However, everyone's skin sensitivity varies. While most people find Allbirds shoes to be extremely comfortable and itch-free, there may be a small number of people who might find them slightly itchy if they wear them without socks. You should also remember that the shoes need a few days of wear to break in fully and become more comfortable.

mainEntity.name: Should slip-on shoes feel tight or loose?

acceptedAnswer.text:
Your slip-on shoes should give you a secure fit without feeling overly constricting. They should feel comfortable and stable, with minimal slippage as you walk. However, it's equally important that they aren't so tight that they cause rubbing or pinching—no one wants discomfort or blisters from tight shoes.

In general, there should be sufficient space in the front part of the shoe (the toe box) for your toes to wiggle freely. Plus, a small gap (roughly the width of your thumb) should exist between your longest toe and the tip of the shoe.

schema_object.name: Men's Slip-Ons FAQ

name: Women's Active Shoes FAQ

ranking.description: This FAQ from a shoe brand focuses primarily on running shoes and their features, which is somewhat relevant to comfort but does not address style or versatility for parties or office wear, limiting its cross-site usefulness for the user's question about nice shoes suitable for both relaxation and social/professional settings.

mainEntity.name: Which Allbirds shoes are best for running?

acceptedAnswer.text:
For everyday runs, we suggest the Tree Dasher 2, which we’ve engineered with our signature ZQ-Certified merino wool and FSC-Certified tree materials for performance, while still having a low impact on the environment. The Tree Dasher 2 has a breathable and flexible eucalyptus tree fiber upper, a responsive midsole made from sugarcane-based SweetFoam, and a natural rubber outsole for traction.

For longer runs, we suggest the Tree Flyer. Lightweight, super springy, and supremely comfortable, this distance running shoe features a cushioned SwiftFoam midsole that also optimizes energy return, making long runs easier on your body, and a breathable eucalyptus tree fiber upper for next-level comfort over any distance.

For off-road and cross-country runners, we suggest the Trail Runners SWT, which feature a lugged outsole designed to provide better grip and traction on various off-road surfaces, a toe bumper for extra protection when navigating rough terrain, and a reinforced heel counter and supportive midsole to provide increased stability and support on uneven surfaces.

mainEntity.name: Are Allbirds shoes good for running?

acceptedAnswer.text:
You better believe it! Three Allbirds shoes designs are made for getting out there and running: The Tree Dasher 2 (everyday runs), Tree Flyers (long-distance runs), and Trail Runners SWT (off-road running). 

Just ask our fans: reviews range from comments like, “my feet are not even on my mind during runs and workouts.” (Danielle S.) to “I love the lightweight feeling and I love how my feet feel when I am running!” (Elizabeth S.)

Not a runner? For explosive HIIT workouts and cross training, try the SuperLight Trainers, weighing in at a barely-there weight of 4 ounces. If golfing is more your jam, hit the course with the Golf Dashers.

mainEntity.name: What is special about running shoes?

acceptedAnswer.text:
Running shoes tend to be lighter in weight than most everyday shoes, with added cushioning for the heel and the toe. They are also more breathable, allowing air to escape and minimizing moisture and humidity—which helps prevent unpleasantness like chafing and blisters. 

Running shoes usually offer more durability than other shoes as well, because they’re typically designed to withstand hundreds of miles of use under harsher conditions.

mainEntity.name: Should you buy running shoes bigger or smaller?

acceptedAnswer.text: You won’t want to buy smaller than your normal shoe size. It’s best to have just a little extra room (about a thumb's width) between your longest toe and the tip of the shoe. If your toe is jamming against the shoe or if the sides of your feet feel pinched, go up a half size. Some people buy their running shoes half a size bigger than their regular shoe size.

schema_object.name: Women's Active Shoes FAQ

name: Lighter Shoes for Warmer Days FAQ

ranking.description: This FAQ page from a credible footwear brand provides detailed information on breathable, comfortable shoes suitable for warm weather, highlighting versatile styles like Tree Runners and SuperLight Trainers that could be appropriate for both casual and semi-formal settings such as parties or offices.

schema_object.@id: Lighter Shoes for Warmer Days FAQ

mainEntity.name: How do I keep my feet cool when wearing shoes?

acceptedAnswer.text: While going barefoot may be the ultimate way to keep your feet cool on hot days, let’s talk about shoe choices. You can keep your feet cool in hot weather by wearing shoes made with breathable materials, choosing socks made from lightweight fabrics, opting for lighter colors that don’t absorb as much heat from the sun, and—we’re totally serious—staying hydrated. That’s right: your hydration level has an effect on your feet.

mainEntity.name: So, what is the most breathable shoe material?

acceptedAnswer.text:
The most breathable shoe materials are typically natural fibers. One standout material that we happen to adore is the remarkably breathable eucalyptus tree fiber.

Eucalyptus tree fiber is a vital material in shoes like our Tree Pipers and Tree Runners. Why is it so great? Because it’s feather-light and breathes easily, providing soft, smooth, and airy comfort that lasts all day. It also has the added advantage of supporting thermo-regulation, preventing your feet from overheating. This breathability is, of course, welcome any time of year, but it pays even bigger dividends on summer’s hottest days. 

Did we mention that eucalyptus tree fiber is renewable? In comparison to conventional materials such as cotton, it requires 95% less water in its production, significantly reducing our water usage. Plus, it cuts our carbon footprint in half. That’s a lot of reasons to try them!

mainEntity.name: What shoes should I have for summer?

acceptedAnswer.text:
Choosing the right shoes for summer is all about combining style, comfort, and function.

While all Allbirds shoes are engineered for breathability, some styles are particularly suited for the warmer summer months. For example, our Wool Runners, crafted with a merino wool exterior, tend to hold more heat compared to the Tree Runners or Tree Dashers, which feature our ultra-breathable eucalyptus tree fiber.

If you're seeking the epitome of breathability and refreshing comfort, our newly launched SuperLight Trainers are an excellent option. These shoes have a novel, airy mesh made from a combination of FSC-certified eucalyptus fiber and recycled monofilament—for a breezier interior. 

And don’t forget slides and flats for all kinds of summer occasions, like our Sugar Sliders and Tree Breezers!

schema_object.name: Lighter Shoes for Warmer Days FAQ

name: Women's Slip-Ons FAQ

ranking.description: This FAQ about women's slip-on shoes provides useful comfort and styling tips relevant to casual wear, but it lacks direct recommendations for shoes suitable for both parties and office settings, limiting its cross-site relevance to the user's question.

mainEntity.name: Is it OK to wear socks with slip-on shoes?

acceptedAnswer.text:
Yes, it's totally fine to wear socks with slip-on shoes. In fact, many people prefer to wear socks with them for a variety of reasons, like comfort, reducing foot sweat and odor, and preventing blisters.

The type of socks you choose can depend on the look you're going for. No-show or low-cut socks are a popular choice as they make you look like you’re rocking bare feet, keeping that minimalistic look that slip-on shoes provide. In the end, your comfort and your styling is the key. If wearing socks with your slip-on shoes makes you more comfortable and feels better, go for it!

mainEntity.name: What kind of socks do you wear with slip-on sneakers?

acceptedAnswer.text: You can wear any style of socks you want with your Allbirds slip-on shoes, but if you’re going for that clean, sockless look, we recommend going with no-show socks like our Trino™ Anytime No Show Sock. Available in multiple sizes, these socks are highly breathable and have reinforced wear points for added durability. And they just so happen to pair perfectly with Allbirds shoes.

mainEntity.name: Should slip-on shoes be tight or loose?

acceptedAnswer.text:
Your slip-on shoes should provide a snug fit, but not be too tight. They should be secure around your feet, with no significant slippage when you walk. At the same time, they shouldn't be so tight that they pinch or rub your feet, which can cause discomfort or blisters. 

Generally, there should be enough room in the toe box for your toes to move freely, and there should be a little space (about a thumb's width) between your longest toe and the end of the shoe.

schema_object.name: Women's Slip-Ons FAQ

name: The Ballet Flats That Do It All FAQ

ranking.description: This FAQ from a reputable footwear brand provides detailed information on ballet flats that are comfortable, versatile, and suitable for various occasions including parties and office wear, aligning well with the user's request for nice shoes to relax in and wear in multiple settings.

schema_object.@id: The Ballet Flats That Do It All FAQ

mainEntity.name: Are the flats comfortable?

acceptedAnswer.text: We may be biased here, but there’s a reason the Tree Breezer flats get stellar reviews. Made with our responsibly sourced eucalyptus tree fiber knit, these flats feel cool, breathable, and silky smooth on your feet. The springy outsoles are made from sugarcane in a material we call SweetFoam®, made with the world’s first carbon negative green EVA. With a bit of ribbing to keep them snug on your foot plus a dash of color if you choose, these flats are extremely comfortable and versatile.

mainEntity.name: Should flats be tight or loose?

acceptedAnswer.text:
Is it ok if we say they should fit ‘just right’? Flats that fit too tightly will cause blisters and pain, especially on your heel and toes. But flats that are too loose will slip around, which can also cause blisters from that friction. And what’s just as bothersome—they won’t stay on your feet.

Like other shoes, flats should be snug enough to not slip when you walk, but not so tight that they hurt. A rule of thumb: there should be a very slight gap between your heel and the shoe.

mainEntity.name: Are flats good for walking?

acceptedAnswer.text:
Go for it! Flats are refreshingly versatile—and that includes being able to wear them walking, shopping, doing errands, and whatever else your day brings. So yes, flats are good for walking.

If you’re looking for a comfortable shoe to wear while standing all day or working on your feet, flats can be a great option instead of heels. Your toes won’t feel as much pressure—and your legs will probably thank you, too. If you’re planning on a long, athletic walk, try the Tree Dasher.

mainEntity.name: Do you wear flats with or without socks?

acceptedAnswer.text:
Most people wear flats without socks. Allbirds flats are made with renewable, silky-smooth eucalyptus tree fiber—a breathable thermo-regulating material that keeps your feet airy and comfy. And if you ever want to wash your Allbirds, you can do so, no sweat. Just take out the insoles and either hand wash or machine wash on gentle/cold. Air dry, and off you go!

Of course, if you want to wear flats with socks, we won’t stop you. You do you.

schema_object.name: The Ballet Flats That Do It All FAQ

Description This Japanese tea cup features the world-famous Japanese ukiyoe (woodblock print) artist Katsushika Hokusai's "Gaifuukaisei (Triumphant Wind and Clear Skies)". The "Gaifuukaisei (Triumphant Wind and Clear Skies)" is one of the 46 paintings in Hokusai Katsushika's famous Ukiyoe series "36 Views of Mount Fuji" and is one of his masterpieces, also known as "Aka-Fuji". It is also one of the most famous works called "Akafuji". It is a perfect gift for Japanese tea lovers. Kutani ware is a traditional craft certified by the Minister of Economy, Trade and Industry, and has been in existence for 360 years since the opening of the first kilns of Old Kutani. Kutani Yaki ware has been exhibited at the Paris Expo and has made a name for itself in the world as Japan Kutani, and is in the collections of famous museums around the world such as the British Museum and the Louvre. Description This is a set of two teacups made of Japanese Kutani ware. The two teacups are different sizes. A large camellia flower is painted in gold and silver. The surface is smooth and shiny, and the overall color is subdued, giving it a luxurious feel. The surface appears to be cracked. This is not a crack but a Kannyu (craze) and is not a quality problem. This is a phenomenon in which the glaze hardens into a crack-like state due to the difference in the degree of shrinkage between the glaze and the base material. Some potters intentionally incorporate Kannyu into their work. The cups are Japanese-style cups called Yunomi, so they do not have handles, but they are made in a shape that is easy to hold. In Japan, there is a tradition of using sets of different sizes for married couples or families. When two are used, they are called "Meoto Yunomi (husband and wife teacups)". They are ideal as gifts for wedding anniversaries for home use or as wedding gifts for acquaintances. schema_object.description: Description This is a tumbler made of Japanese Kutani ware. It is made using a technique called hanazume, a technique that has been used since the Taisho Period (1912-26). Hanazume is a decoration in which flowers are packed together without gaps. The white background of this product allows the colors of the flowers to shine through. Delicate and precise golden lines are used, making the tableware look like a work of art. The single gold line near the bottom accentuates the elegance. It is full of the charm of traditional Japanese craftsmanship. A portion of the side is concave, making it easy to hold. Since the cup weighs a good amount when filled with tea or other beverages, it is important to make it easy to hold. In addition to its beauty, this attractive tumbler has ease of use and a unique design. It is recommended for both home use and as a gift. schema_object.description: Description This is a teacup made of Japanese Kutani ware. The design depicts a white cat and a black cat cuddling in the sun. The design is perfect for a break. Matcha bowls are used in the Japanese tea ceremony. It is used to serve tea called matcha. It features a wider point than other cups because matcha needs to be stirred after it is poured into the bowl. Therefore, in addition to tea, it is also suitable for soup and other drinks that require a small spoon. The cup is made in a shape that is easy to hold with both hands and can be handled safely with little danger of slipping out of the hand. It comes with a wooden box and is especially recommended as a gift. It will be appreciated if it is a gift for someone who knows the tea ceremony. It is also recommended for home use as it can be used for many purposes. schema_object.name: Kutani Ware Pair Yunomi（Japanese tea cup）with Blossoms
schema_object.description: Description This set of large and small teacups is made of Japanese Kutani ware. Both are decorated with a cherry blossom pattern. The larger one has flowers in blue, and the smaller one in red. The surface appears to be cracked. This is not a crack but a Kannyu (craze) and is not a quality problem. This is a phenomenon in which the glaze hardens into a crack-like state due to the difference in the degree of shrinkage between the glaze and the base material. Some potters intentionally incorporate Kannyu into their work. This set of teacups is suitable for both daily use and as a gift. In Japan, it is customary for couples or lovers to use a pair of dishes of different sizes. Use it with your partner at home. Give it as a gift to a married friend. These products are suitable for such uses. schema_object.name: Kutani Ware Pair Yunomi (Japanese tea cup) with Gold and Silver Camellia
schema_object.description: Description This is a set of two teacups made of Japanese Kutani ware. The two teacups are different sizes. A large camellia flower is painted in gold and silver. The surface is smooth and shiny, and the overall color is subdued, giving it a luxurious feel. The surface appears to be cracked. This is not a crack but a Kannyu (craze) and is not a quality problem. This is a phenomenon in which the glaze hardens into a crack-like state due to the difference in the degree of shrinkage between the glaze and the base material. Some potters intentionally incorporate Kannyu into their work. The cups are Japanese-style cups called Yunomi, so they do not have handles, but they are made in a shape that is easy to hold. In Japan, there is a tradition of using sets of different sizes for married couples or families. When two are used, they are called "Meoto Yunomi (husband and wife teacups)". They are ideal as gifts for wedding anniversaries for home use or as wedding gifts for acquaintances. schema_object.name: Kutani Ware Japanese Pair Cup with Gold Leaf
schema_object.description: Description This is a sake cup made with "Kinsai," a typical Japanese Kutani ware technique. Kinsai is a technique in which gold leaf is cut away to create a pattern in the gaps, and then fired with a highly transparent glaze. organizer.description: Shepherd’s Harvest Festival is an opportunity for rural and urban people to meet and share information about sheep and sheep products and other fiber-producing animals. The Festival was started in order to provide a venue where wool producers, wool consumers and wool artisans could come together and share the excitement of working with sheep and their fantastic product – wool. Gradually, the Festival has grown to include other fiber animals such as angora rabbits, alpacas, and goats.The Festival strives to be a family oriented event that is not only fun but educational. Numerous classes are offered in the fiber arts — geared for all levels of experience — from the beginner to the expert.Each year, we offer some classes in the less well known fiber arts so students can expand their crafts expertise Many vendors of fiber and fiber animal related products show their wares at the Festival through a juried selection of vendors of unique products. If it’s fiber related, you probably will find a vendor with just what you have been looking for.

acceptedAnswer.text: Yes, family members of all ages are welcome. We will be using art materials of all kinds which may include scissors, glue, paint, etc. As caretakers, we ask that you keep an eye on your loved one so that every can enjoy the space.

mainEntity.name: Is event suitable for families?

acceptedAnswer.text: Yes! We all have stories to tell so take a chance, meet some new people and get creative. There will be people of all ages at the event.

mainEntity.name: Is this event suitable for individuals?

acceptedAnswer.text: The event is mostly seated. There is  an icebreaker at the beginning of each event, which may involved some movement. If you have accessibility issues, please let us know so we can accommodate. You can always make the choice for yourself about what feels best.

mainEntity.name: Will I have to move during the event?

acceptedAnswer.text: Yes! At the end of each event, food will be offered. The food can range from snacks to meals depending on the day. This is a six part series so each event will have something different. We hope you enjoy the offerings!

mainEntity.name: Will there be food at the event?

acceptedAnswer.text: Yes, you can arrive by 3:30pm the latest. You may not have time to complete the project, but you'll have most of the materials and can complete your art at home. Not all materials are guaranteed with late arrival. Please note that the end time is still 4:30pm regardless of a later arrival.

mainEntity.name: Is it OK to arrive after the start time?

acceptedAnswer.text: Please let us know as soon as you can. If all members of your party do not attend, then the materials will be given to someone on the waitlist or walk-in. The aim is to keep the program equitable and accessible.

mainEntity.name: What happens if part of my group cannot attend?

acceptedAnswer.text: Materials are planned for in advance based on the number of registrants. If all members of your party do not attend, then the materials will be given to someone on the waitlist or walk-in. The aim is to keep the program equitable and accessible.

mainEntity.name: Once I finish my creative piece, can I create one for a loved one or friend?

acceptedAnswer.text: Please let us know as soon as you can so someone else can enjoy the event. We usually have a waitlist, so we can inform the person in advance. The aim is to keep the program equitable and accessible.

mainEntity.name: What happens if I cannot attend?

acceptedAnswer.text: I'll have a few resources ready by the time the workshop is ready, and provide a resource packet for any one who has signed up. But I will leave it up to the participants what methods they want to try to make these cards. My mission is to provide creative support without stressing anyone out.

mainEntity.name: Do you plan to go over digital tools for content creation of cards?

acceptedAnswer.text: I'd be sad if no one wanted to try making them. But again, I leave that to whomever wants to attend the group.

mainEntity.name: Do you have time to make origami folded envelopes?

acceptedAnswer.text: We can talk about the ways we can build an assembly line style construction project for collage style card pieces, or see whether or not the same design works flat and printed.  As with many artworks, it often helps to talk about what you as the artist are looking for before making decisions.

mainEntity.name: I want to make the same card for all of my family. How can I do that?

recipeInstructions.text: Firstly, in a bowl take ¾ cup chana dal and ¾ cup toor dal. Adding the mixture of toor and chana dal gives nice crunchiness and taste.

recipeInstructions.text: Transfer the soaked dal into the mixer jar.
recipeInstructions.name: Transfer the soaked dal into the mixer jar.

recipeInstructions.text: Add 2 dried red chilli, 1 tsp cumin andd 1 tsp fennel.
recipeInstructions.name: Add 2 dried red chilli, 1 tsp cumin andd 1 tsp fennel.

recipeInstructions.text: Pulse and grind to a coarse paste. You can also use a chopper to prevent it from turning into a smooth paste.

recipeInstructions.text: Transfer the dal paste to a large bowl.

recipeInstructions.text: Add 2 tbsp onion, 1 inch ginger, few curry leaves, 2 chilli, ¾ tsp salt and mix well.

recipeInstructions.text: Squeeze and mix making sure everything is well combined. If you find the mixture is watery, then add 2 tbsp rice flour.

recipeInstructions.text: Now wet your hand or grease your hand and pinch a ball-sized mixture.

recipeInstructions.text: Flatten slightly with your palm, make sure to keep the edges thin compared to the centre.
recipeInstructions.name: Flatten slightly with your palm, make sure to keep the edges thin compared to the centre.

recipeInstructions.text: Drop the vada into hot oil, keeping the flame on medium.
recipeInstructions.name: Drop the vada into hot oil, keeping the flame on medium.

recipeInstructions.text: Do not touch the vada for 2 minutes, else there are chances for the vada to break.
recipeInstructions.name: Do not touch the vada for 2 minutes, else there are chances for the vada to break.

recipeInstructions.text: Stir occasionally, and fry on low to medium flame.
recipeInstructions.name: Stir occasionally, and fry on low to medium flame.

recipeInstructions.text: Fry until the vada turns golden and crunchy.
recipeInstructions.name: Fry until the vada turns golden and crunchy.

recipeInstructions.text: Drain off and keep aside. Make sure to fry on low to medium flame, or else the vada will turn crispy from out and remain soft from the inside.
recipeInstructions.name: Drain off and keep aside. Make sure to fry on low to medium flame, or else the vada will turn crispy from out and remain soft from the inside.

recipeInstructions.text: Finally, Masala Vada Recipe tastes great for up to 2 days when stored in an airtight container.
